{{de icon}} ''KÃ¶nigreich Belgien'' | conventional_long_name = Kingdom of Belgium | common_name = Belgium |image_map = Location Belgium EU Europe.png }} '''Euro gold and silver commemorative coins''' are special [[euro coins]] [[Mint (coin)|minted]] and issued by member states of the [[Eurozone]], mainly in [[gold]] and [[silver]], although other [[precious metal]]s are also used in rare occasions. [[Belgium]] was one of the first twelve countries in the Eurozone that introduced the [[Euro|euro (â¬)]] on 1 January 2002. Since then, the Belgian Royal Mint have been minting both normal issues of [[Belgian euro coins]], which are intended for circulation, and commemorative euro coins in gold and silver. These special coins are only [[legal tender]] in Belgium, unlike the normal issues of the Belgian euro coins, which are legal tender in every country of the Eurozone. This means that the commemorative coins made of gold and silver cannot be used as money in other countries. Furthermore, as their [[Precious metal#Bullion|bullion value]]Precious metals in bulk form are known as ''bullion'', and are traded on [[commodity market]]s. Bullion metals may be cast into [[ingot]]s, or minted into [[coin]]s. The defining attribute of bullion is that it is valued by its mass and purity rather than by a [[face value]] as [[money]]. generally vastly exceeds their face value, these coins are not intended to be used as means of payment at allâalthough it remains possible. For this reason, they are usually named '''Collectors' coins'''. The coins usually [[Commemorative coin|commemorate]] the [[Anniversary|anniversaries]] of [[History|historical events]] or draw attention to [[current events]] of special importance. Belgium mints five of these coins on average per year, in both gold and silver, with face value ranging from 10 to 100 euros. All the coins were designed by [[Luc Luycx]]. == Summary == As of 3 July 2008, 27 variations of Belgian commemorative coins have been minted: two in 2002, two in 2003, four in 2004, four in 2005, six in 2006, six in 2007, seven in 2008 and two in 2009 so far. These special high-value commemorative coins are not to be confused with [[â¬2 commemorative coins]], which are coins designated for circulation and do have legal tender status in all countries of the Eurozone.{{cite web | publisher=[[European Commission]] | url=http://ec.europa.eu/economy_finance/the_euro/notes_coins8787_en.htm | title=Different types of euro coins | accessdate=2008-06-24}} {{dead link|date=June 2011}} The following table shows the number of coins minted per year. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 100 euro. |} == 2003 coinage == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="white-space:nowrap; width:330px; text-align:center;"| ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 100th Anniversary of Georges Simenon |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2003 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|33|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.75|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| Although his well-known protagonist, [[Jules Maigret|Detective Inspector Maigret]], was [[Paris]]ian, [[Georges Simenon]] was one of most famous [[List of Belgians#Authors|Belgian writers]] of the 20th century. Two of them, ''My Friend Maigret'' (1949) and ''Maigret in Court'' (1960) were named in 1987 as two of the hundred best crime novels. For his work particularly on police novels, Belgium has chosen to honor the centennial of his birth (13 February 1903) with a 10-euro sterling silver commemorative coin.{{cite web | url=http://www.coin-currency.com/belgian.html | publisher=The coin and currency institute of Belgium | accessdate=2008-06-24 | title=100th Anniversary of Georges Simenon commemorative coin |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080417054627/http://www.coin-currency.com/belgian.html |archivedate = 2008-04-17}} The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] front side shows his portrait. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed in the middle as well as the nominal value of 100 euro. |} == 2004 coinage == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="width:330px; white-space:nowrap;"|   ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| 75th Anniversary of [[The Adventures of Tintin|Kuifje (Tintin)]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2004 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|33|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.75|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The coin celebrates the 75th anniversary of the famous Belgian cartoon ''[[Tintin]]'', also known as ''Kuifje''. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 10 euro, surrounded by the 12 stars of the union. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|   |- | rowspan="4"|   ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Enlargement of the European Union#Eastern bloc enlargements|Fifth Enlargement of the European Union]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (silver) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2004 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|33|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.75|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The female character [[Europa (mythology)|Europa]], abducted by Zeus, watching the continent from the skies, is shown on the obverse of the coin. The continent [[Europe]] has ultimately been named after this female character. In the eighth century, ecclesiastical uses of ''Europa'' for the imperium of [[Charlemagne]] provide the source for the modern geographical term. The name of Europe as a geographical term came in use by [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] geographers such as [[Strabo]].Strabo, Geography [http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/cgi-bin/ptext?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0197:book=8:chapter=1:section=1 8.1.1] It is derived from the [[Greek language|Greek]] word ''Europa'' (ÎÏÏÏÏÎ·) in almost all European languages. Europa has been used frequently as a [[European symbols#Europa|symbol of Europe]]; statues of her and the bull, are placed outside several European Union institutions. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 50 euro, surrounded by the 12 stars of the union. |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"|   |- | rowspan="4"|   ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| The [[Enlargement of the European Union#Eastern bloc enlargements|Fifth European Union Expansion]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬100 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999 (gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 5,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2004 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|29|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|15.55|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| On 1 May 2004, eight of the old [[Communist state|communist countries]] ([[Czech Republic]], [[Estonia]], [[Hungary]], [[Latvia]], [[Lithuania]], [[Poland]], [[Slovakia]], and [[Slovenia]]), plus the [[Mediterranean]] islands of [[Malta]] and [[Cyprus]], joined the union. This was the largest single enlargement in terms of people and landmass, although the smallest in terms of [[Gross domestic product|GDP]].{{cite web | url=http://europa.eu/abc/history/2000_today/index_en.htm | title=Europa, History of EU 2000-present | accessdate=2008-06-24 | publisher=[[European Commission]]}} To commemorate this remarkable event, the Belgian mint minted this gold commemorative coin. The obverse shows ten famous landmarks, each of them located in one of the ten new members of the European Union, surrounding the euro symbol with the 12 stars of the union. The reverse shows the new map of the union, with the new members added. The stadium, also known as ''King Baudouin Stadium'' (French: ''Stade Roi Baudouin'', Dutch: ''Koning Boudewijnstadion''), is a sports ground in north-west [[Brussels]]. It was inaugurated on 23 August 1930 (days after Belgium's 100th anniversary) as the ''Stade du JubilÃ©'' or ''Jubelstadion'' ("Jubilee Stadium") in the presence of [[Leopold III of Belgium|Prince Leopold III]]. It was built to embellish the ''Heysel plateau'' in view of the 1935 [[World's Fair]]. The stadium hosted 70,000 people at the time. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 100 euro. |} == 2006 coinage == {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- | rowspan="4" style="width:330px; white-space:nowrap;"|   ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| [[Justus Lipsius]] |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬10 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Ag 925 (silver) & Cu 75 (Copper) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 50,000 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|33|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|18.75|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | rowspan="4"|   ! colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#eee;"| Justus Lipsius |- style="text-align:center;" | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Designer:''' Luc Luycx | colspan="2" style="width:50%; "| '''Mint:''' Royal Belgian Mint |- | align=center | '''Value:''' â¬50 | align=center | '''Alloy:''' Au 999 (gold) | align=center | '''Quantity:''' 2,500 | align=center | '''Quality:''' proof |- | align=center | '''Issued:''' 2006 | align=center | '''Diameter:''' {{convert|21|mm|in|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | '''Weight:''' {{convert|6.22|g|oz ozt|2|abbr=on}} | align=center | |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:left;"| The 400th anniversary of the death of Belgian philosopher [[Justus Lipsius]] is the theme of Belgium's contribution to the [[Europa Coins 2006|2006 Europa coin program]] of famous European personalities. Born in 1547, Lipsius came to be known for his writings on stoicism. The most famous of these was entitled ''De Constantia'' ("On Constancy"), and in it he spoke of the merits of a Stoic-inspired ideal of constancy whenever people were faced with unpleasant events or circumstances. His teachings led to a philosophical movement known today as "[[Neostoicism]]". Lipsius died in 1606.{{cite web | url=http://www.eurocollections.com/catalog/?product=2086 | title=Belgium 2006 10â¬ Justus Lipsivs silver proof | publisher=Euro Collections International | accessdate=2008-06-24 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} The [[Obverse and reverse|obverse]] of the coin features an image of Lipsius, surrounded by the inscription of his name and the dates 1547â1606. The [[Obverse and reverse|reverse]] shows a map of Europe as one continent. "Belgium" in the three official languages is displayed as well as the nominal value of 10 euro, surrounded by the 12 stars of the European Union.
